description: Uncertain; compare (probably from) Danish simper / semper (“coy”), German zimper (“elegant, dainty”).

entries.meaning: A foolish, frivolous, self-conscious, or affected smile; a smirk.

verbs.description: simper (third-person singular simple present simpers, present participle simpering, simple past and past participle simpered)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To smile in a foolish, frivolous, self-conscious, coy, obsequious, or smug manner.
examples: How the fools kotowed and simpered while I looked over their jewels and speculated upon how much I could get for them!
Yet can I mark how stars above / Simper and shine.
